summary: Stomach cancer is a malignant tumor that develops in the lining of the stomach due to abnormal cell growth. It most commonly affects older individuals and can spread to other parts of the body. Early diagnosis is challenging due to non-specific symptoms, often leading to advanced disease at presentation. The prognosis is generally poor, especially for advanced cases.
causes: Genetic syndromes (e.g., hereditary diffuse gastric cancer)
risk_factors: Salted, smoked, or pickled foods consumption
symptoms: Yellowing of the skin and whites of the eyes
Bloating of the stomach after meals
diagnosis: Imaging tests (e.g., CT scan, PET scan, abdominal ultrasound)
Tumor markers (e.g., carcinoembryonic antigen, carbohydrate antigen)
treatments: Surgery (e.g., gastrectomy, endoscopic mucosal resection, endoscopic submucosal dissection)
Chemotherapy (e.g., 5-fluorouracil, cisplatin, epirubicin, etoposide, docetaxel, oxaliplatin, capecitabine, irinotecan)
Targeted therapy (e.g., trastuzumab for HER2-overexpressing cancer)
Treatment of H. pylori infection (for MALT lymphomas)
subtypes: Extranodal marginal zone B-cell lymphomas (MALT type)
